issue.title: Updated picnic to v2.2.
issue.body:
Updated picnic to v2.2. From the changelog:

- Fix Picnic2 implementation on big endian systems
- Add support for SHA3/SHAKE3 instructions on IBM z.
- Various small improvements and bug fixes.
- Remove LowMC instances with m=1.

comment.body: All tests pass on `clang-10` with the requested changes made.

issue.title: Increase max size for signatures in speed.c
issue.body:
Increases max signature sizes for speed tests to 35000 (enough for picnicl1fs). Test code is hard to read, but it uses the last value of `lengths_list` array to allocate the signature buffer in the OQS tests. We'll need to update this value as we add algs with larger sigs.

Fixes issue #159.

comment.body:
> Something else with picnic must have changed, though, as the error couldn't be triggered any more (before applying this patch!) by running picnic alone (as was the case when I created the issue). Whatever, case closed!

The speed tool crashed for me at different point on different machines (sometimes during signing, sometime during verification). Probably depends on the state of the heap, which could vary I suppose from machine to machine, debug vs. release, etc.

> Before merging, would you please remove the two references to `OPENSSL_NO_CLEANUP` to re-activate full testing (one in `apps/speed.c` and one in `oqs_test/scripts/do_openssl-speed.sh`)? 

Will do.

issue.title: Increase max size for signatures in speed.c
issue.body:
Increases max signature sizes for speed tests to 35000 (enough for picnicl1fs). Test code is hard to read, but it uses the last value of `lengths_list` array to allocate the signature buffer in the OQS tests. We'll need to update this value as we add algs with larger sigs.

Fixes issue #159.

comment.body:
@baentsch, in `do_openssl-speed.sh`, shouldn't there be another return code check after running the sig tests, just like with the KEMs:

```
if [ $? -ne 0 ]; then
   exit -1
fi
```

comment.body: @yogitagolhani : Is there anything else we could do to help beyond the explanation that @xvzcf provided above? We try to close issues after a week if no further discussion occurs. I'll do that soon then... but you can of course always reopen/ask for further clarifications.

issue.title: Increase max size for signatures in speed.c
issue.body:
Increases max signature sizes for speed tests to 35000 (enough for picnicl1fs). Test code is hard to read, but it uses the last value of `lengths_list` array to allocate the signature buffer in the OQS tests. We'll need to update this value as we add algs with larger sigs.

Fixes issue #159.

comment.body: @christianpaquin No, such code would not be necessary: The last command run provides the exit code for the whole script: If it fails, the script fails (and vice versa). But it also shouldn't hurt.

issue.title: Enable build on Windows
issue.body: The Makefile needs to be rewritten for Windows.

comment.body:
OK, I finally have some bandwidth to test the Windows maven build. I'm not getting as far, @vsoftco: when trying to build the windows package (`-P windows`):

```
mvn package -P windows  -Dliboqs.include.dir="c:\dev\github\liboqs\build\include" -Dliboqs.lib.dir="c:\dev\github\liboqs\build\lib"
```

 I get an error that `gcc` isn't found (see error below). Do you notice something wrong? Shouldn't the windows package call `cl` automatically?

```
[INFO] --- native-maven-plugin:1.0-alpha-9:compile (generate-shared-oqs-library) @ liboqs-java ---
[INFO] cmd.exe /X /C "gcc -IC:\Program Files\Java\jdk-14/include -IC:\Program Files\Java\jdk-14/include/win32 -fPIC -Wall -O3 -Ic:\dev\github\liboqs\build\include -Ic:\dev\github\liboqs-java\src\main\c -Ic:\dev\github\liboqs-java\target\generated-sources\annotations -oc:\dev\github\liboqs-java\target\objs\handle.obj -c c:\dev\github\liboqs-java\src\main\c\handle.c"
[INFO] ------------------------------------------------------------------------
[INFO] BUILD FAILURE
[INFO] ------------------------------------------------------------------------
[INFO] Total time:  3.184 s
[INFO] Finished at: 2020-05-07T13:59:36-04:00
[INFO] ------------------------------------------------------------------------
[ERROR] Failed to execute goal org.codehaus.mojo:native-maven-plugin:1.0-alpha-9:compile (generate-shared-oqs-library) on project liboqs-java: Error executing command line: Error while executing process. Cannot run program "gcc" (in directory "c:\dev\github\liboqs-java"): CreateProcess error=2, The system cannot find the file specified -> [Help 1]
```

Anything obvious to you?

issue.title: Enable build on Windows
issue.body: The Makefile needs to be rewritten for Windows.

comment.body:
I didn't have a chance to setup OQS in Windows yet.

We haven't defined different native compilers in `pom.xml`, `gcc` is hardcoded for now. Can you try changing lines [129](https://github.com/open-quantum-safe/liboqs-java/blob/master/pom.xml#L129) and [138](https://github.com/open-quantum-safe/liboqs-java/blob/master/pom.xml#L138) in `pom.xml` and see if it works?

If that works, I can define different compilers for different OSes in the profiles section like it is for the [shared jni library](https://github.com/open-quantum-safe/liboqs-java/blob/master/pom.xml#L50).

issue.title: Enable build on Windows
issue.body: The Makefile needs to be rewritten for Windows.

comment.body: Oh, I see. There are a few more things to tweak, as the Windows compiler options are not the same as gcc. I'm curious how @vsoftco packaged the wrapper on Windows.

issue.title: Failed setting curve list
issue.body:
On writing a code "tool/bssl client -curves <KEX> -connect localhost:4433", i am getting error 
**Failed setting curves list**

I have tried with these syntaxes:
1. tool/bssl client -curves oqs_kemdefault -connect localhost:4433
2.tool/bssl client -curves frodo640aes -connect localhost:4433
3.tool/bssl client -curves p256_frodo640aes -connect localhost:4433


Also, I am trying to do the setup by installing docker on top of windows10 operating system and inside docker , i have installed ubuntu and then trying to do the setu of boringssl to start with chromim demo

comment.body: I'm not able to reproduce this on my Ubuntu 19.10 machine. What sequence of build steps did you run?

issue.title: Updated picnic to v2.2.
issue.body:
Updated picnic to v2.2. From the changelog:

- Fix Picnic2 implementation on big endian systems
- Add support for SHA3/SHAKE3 instructions on IBM z.
- Various small improvements and bug fixes.
- Remove LowMC instances with m=1.

comment.body: Looks good for me. I'll wait for @dstebila's approval.

issue.title: Overhauled test suite.
issue.body: The speed tests have been temporarily taken out the CI. Once, `openssl speed` can parse OQS key-exchanges in the form of the names given [here](https://github.com/open-quantum-safe/openssl/blob/OQS-OpenSSL_1_1_1-stable/oqs-template/generate.yml#L3), a parallelized version of the KEM and SIG tests can be added to a nightly build.

comment.body: @xvzcf Have you tested your Python scripts to make sure that they actually report failures when they occur?  If I recall correctly in the past we didn't always test that in our bash scripts, and failures went through unreported.

issue.title: Sync with upstream OpenSSH v8.2-p1 release

comment.body:
This is a bit more complicated than I expected; although not that surprising given that going from v7 to v8 is a major release. I did an initial merge of the code ([here](https://github.com/christianpaquin/openssh-portable/tree/cp-v8_2)); there is some code that will need to be reviewed for potentially unknown side-effects, and I'm having trouble compiling the project because the build instructions changed (see the [build from git](https://github.com/christianpaquin/openssh-portable/tree/cp-v8_2) section of the README).

I'll put this on the ice for now, and get back to more immediate priorities. I'll get back to it later, or I'm happy to pass the baton to someone else.
